However, I advise you to take that one off before your father and sisters come home; though I suppose they intend to make a night of it all day; for 'tis morning already! Pray, Miss Cinderella, how did you find your way home?

sp.speaker: Cin.
sp.p: I scarcely know. The way seemed to me as though it never would end.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: That's exactly what it seemed to me, though I'm sure I ran as fast as any rat of 'em all. I got out just in time to see the pumpkin turning a corner, and after it I ran like mad! Oh, if the dear good Fairy would only patronize us once more! I'll just blow-in the fire a little, perhaps she may favour us again by dropping down the chimney. (blowing the fire and singing) “Morning is dawning brightly, love,” “Then prithee, come down, come down!” (shaking his head) No, she won't come down.

sp.speaker: Baron
sp.p: (without L.H.) Pedro!

sp.speaker: Clorinda.
sp.p: (without L.) Pedro! Cinderella!

sp.speaker: Thisbe.
sp.p: (without L.) Cinderella!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: There they are;—Let me run up stairs first to them, I dare say we shall hear a fine account of ourselves. Exeunt, L.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: An apartment in the Baron's house.
Enter Baron, Clorinda, and Thisbe, L.H., followed by Pedro.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: What's the reason, sirrah, you were not at the door to receive us? 'Tis not so early but you might have risen three hours ago, and watched for us.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I have not risen at all to day, Master, for I never lay down, neither I nor Miss Cinderella.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Miss, indeed!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I'm sure I never call her anything else, Miss.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Go and call Miss here, then.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Poor soul! she hasn't stirred from the chimney corner all night, no! no more than myself. I hope you enjoyed yourself at the ball, Baron?

sp.speaker: Baron
sp.p: (ill temperedly) What's that to you, you inquisitive rascal?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I should have thought it likely from all the capers you practised yesterday.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Begone, you impudent dog, or my cane shall practise a caper upon your head! Get out, you ugly varlet, or I shall lose my patience!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Don't do that, Sir, you've so little, it would be a pity to part with it.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: The Baron shall part with you though, and a good riddance we shall all have of you. Begone! and call Cinderella. Oh, here she comes.

div.stage: Enter Cinderella, L.H.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: (aside to Cinderella) My dear young lady, find out if they smoked the rats and the pumpkin. Exit L.H.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: So you're there! I think you might have kept awake, forsooth, till our return!

sp.speaker: Cin.
sp.p: It's no wonder I should tire, considering how long you have staid.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: Ah! if you had been at the ball, you would have been as little tired as we are. Oh! we had a gay time of it, and there came thither the finest Princess, the most beautiful ever seen with mortal eyes!

sp.speaker: Cin.
sp.p: (crosses to Thisbe) A Princess!

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: Yes, and she was so taken with us that she shewed us a thousand civilities.

sp.speaker: Cin.
sp.p: And pray, what was the name of this Princess, sister,—I mean—Miss Thisbe?

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: That nobody knows; and what's more, she left the palace immediately the clock struck twelve, in such a singular way, that nobody can tell what became of her.

sp.speaker: Cin.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: And what is quite as singular, my dears, it seems that the guards at the palace gates said nobody had gone out, but a young girl, who looked more like a poor country wench than a gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: The only trace they found of her was a little glass slipper, which she let fall as she hastened away.

sp.speaker: Cin.
sp.p: (anxiously) A glass—slipper!

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: It is to be sure the prettiest little thing.—one would suppose it had been worked by the hand of fairies.

div.stage: Enter Pedro in flurried haste with a paper, L.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Oh! such news! such news! such wonderful news!

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: (hastily) Is the Prince come again?—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: No—not the Prince exactly, but a royal post! and he has brought us this copy of a proclamation which he says is now being proclaimed through the city by sound of trumpet and drum.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A proclamation?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Yes; the post ran away the moment he left it, because he had more to deliver, and when I opened it I found—

sp.speaker: Clor and This.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I could make nothing of it.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Because I can't read.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Let me see it. (takes paper)

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: No, papa, let me. (snatching it)

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: I'm the eldest, Miss, and must see it first. (snatches it away)

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: Not before me. (snatches again at it, and tears the paper in half.)

sp.speaker: Clor. &This.
sp.p: (each holding up a piece reproachfully) There!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: There! There's a proclamation a piece now.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: How now, girls! what's the meaning of this— vivacity? By the beards of my ancestors, I've a great mind to grow into a passion.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Well, there, papa, you shall read it first. (gives Baron her piece)

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: Yes, there, Sir. (gives Baron the other piece)

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Read it first? How the devil am I to read it at all now? (puts papers together) Stay—that's it.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Now for it.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Silence! (reads) “Proclamation by Supreme Command”—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Just what the royal post said!

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Hold your peace, sirrah! (reads) —“We, Felix the First, ruler of this Principality, do hereby make known that we will take to wife, and share our heart and throne with her whom the glassy slipper found at our last night's ball shall fit”—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Eh!

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: (reading) “Felix, Princeps—Given under our Royal Seal at our Palace this”—

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: (interrupting) Marry her whom the slipper shall fit! (looks at her foot) Let's go back directly, Sir.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: Oh! yes, yes! let's make haste, papa!

sp.speaker: Cin.
sp.p: (aside with emotion) Have I heard rightly!

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: I'm perfectly sure it will fit me, if a pretty foot is to carry it.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: (aside) There must be nice paring down of nails if it does!

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Which is my smallest foot, Pedro?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Why, that's rather a puzzling question, Miss; for I don't think one's smaller than the other—they're both a nice size.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: You think, then, I shall get the slipper on?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I think, Miss, that if you try, you'll be very likely to put your foot in it.

sp.speaker: Cin.
sp.p: (to Baron) Oh, Sir, may I not be permitted to go with you this time?

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: You? The girl is mad!

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: You? ha! ha! ha! What insolence! Perhaps you would like to try the slipper too?

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! that would be a sight! The Princess Cinderella! ha! ha! ha! I wonder what people would think if they were to see such a creature as you with us!

sp.speaker: Cin.
sp.p: I would tell them that I was your servant, and it would be but the truth.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: I am thinking, though, what in the name of wonder the Prince will do, if this curious trial should prove of no avail.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Perhaps, in that case, he'll marry the slipper!

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Come, let us make haste back to the Palace. I'm quite certain one of ye will be a Queen yet—yes, yes, I didn't dream I was an ass for nothing.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Good bye, Princess Cinderella! Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: Adieu your Highness! Ha, ha, ha!

div.stage: Exeunt Baron, Clorinda, and Thisbe laughing, L.H.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: (mocking their laughing) Hish! hish! hish! Devil take your sniggering!

sp.speaker: Cin.
sp.p: (dejectedly) Well, Pedro, must I stay behind them?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Stay behind them? not a minute. If you stay behind any one it shall be behind me, for I'll put a pillion on the blind mare, and we'll trot away after them.

sp.speaker: Cin.
sp.p: Ah! but Pedro—this mean dress, this wretched appearance—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: It doesn't matter for your dress, all that's wanted is the length of your foot.

sp.speaker: Cin.
sp.p: But I shall be refused a trial.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p:
Not when they look in your face. Only give them a smile, and point out your toe, and you're sure to kick down all objections. Besides, I'll announce you myself to the Prince—that I will. He thought me a nobleman, you know, the last time he saw my figure; now that it's less
covered with finery, he'll see it plainer, and I've no doubt he'll think me an ambassador in disguise.

sp.speaker: Cin.
sp.p: Well, Pedro, I will venture, and if the Fairy disappoints my hopes, I can but die.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Die! If ever I saw you do such a foolish thing, I'd never forgive you. Die, indeed! Mind my prophetic words:—You'll live yet to be a Princess renowned in universal history books! Such a Princess as there never was before, and never will be again! And, Miss Cinderella, when you have changed your chimney stool for a princely throne, and have learned the hocus pocus of making lords and such kind of gentry, don't neglect to give poor Pedro a turn, and my arms, and those of my noble family, shall be ever after a pumpkin supported by two rats! Come along, put your shoe in your pocket, and hey for the pillion and the blind mare!

div.stage: Exeunt L.H.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: A Hall in the Prince's Palace. In the centre of the room, a square pedestal by which, on a golden cushion, lies the glass slipper. Two female attendants near it. A lady is discovered making the trial, which is unsuccessful; she descends to make way for another, joining a numerous group of disappointed candidates. (Music)
The Prince is discovered seated on R.H., Alidoro, Dandini, and Two Pages standing by him, anxiously watching the trial.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: (relieved by the unsuccessful attempt) My heart is lightened of its fears. Though I have ta'en this way to discover, if possible, the lovely owner of this curious toy, it were a cruel torture to my heart, if chance destroyed my hopes!

div.stage: Enter Page L. H.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: The Baron and the Ladies of Pumpolino are in the ante-chamber.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p:
(coldly) Admit them. (Exit Page, L.H.) I dread
the trial, (to Alidoro) lest vanity and insolence should claim my hand.
sp.stage: Enter Baron, Clorinda, and Thisbe, L.H.
sp.p: Baron, and gentle ladies, well are ye come. The trial you are apprised of is in our presence, and you, Baron, may superintend your daughters' essay with our free leave.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Gracious Prince, that is assuredly to me and to my daughters, as well as to my daughters and to me, a most flattering and considerate indulgence.

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: (simpering) Sweet Prince, if fated by Fortune my foot should fit—

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Your foot, sister!—your foot's like a— (passes Thisbe and curtseys to Prince) 'Tis for me I've no doubt, Prince, the honour is reserved.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: (coldly) The event, Madam, will show.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Now, daughters (takes slipper and kneels on cushion)

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: I'm quite ready, Sir. (runs before Clorinda to pedestal)

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Forward little minx! She's always the first!

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: (looks at the slipper) Bless me, what a little thing it is!

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: (trying to force on the slipper, aside to her) Make your foot small!

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: (shrinking) Oh dear me! it will never go on!

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: (exulting) I thought so!

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: What the plague have you got in your stocking?

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: My foot is too long, Pa!

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Where the deuce is your heel? (the Baron forces the slipper violently; Thisbe screams, and comes down disappointed and limping)

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: (triumphantly) I knew how it would be, sister. simpering and curtseying to Prince) I'm convinced by the size it's just my measure. (ascends the pedestal) Now, Sir! The Baron, with the slipper, makes an effort evidently painful to Clorinda. Oh! gently, Papa! La! you're so awkward!

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Awkward, indeed! (pushes slipper again)

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: (making a grimace) Oh! do you want to cripple me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Never mind, child: the honour of being a Princess is well worth a lame foot. (aloud suddenly) There! it's on!

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: (starts up) How!

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: All but the heel! (the Prince sits down) Courage, my dear. (pushing slipper again)

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: (screams) Oh! I can't bear it any more—the slipper's too short.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: No, my dear—it's your foot that's too long— (with a violent and final push)

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Ah! (screams loudly and descends enraged)

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: (trimphantly) I knew how it would be, sister. (laughs)

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: (aside) If I could only have foreseen this thirty years ago, they should both have had Chinese treatment.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: (aside) Fortune! again I thank thee!

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.p: (without L.H.) You must not advance.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: (without L.H.) Nonsense, I will advance.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.p: Stand back, I say!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I won't go back!

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: What noise is that?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I'll have my say out, if I die for it. Enter Pedro, L.H. Noble Prince!

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: What insolence is this? Hence, fellow, or—

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Stay! What seek you in this place, friend?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Most magnificent, extravagant, and dreadful Prince, whose countenance is shocking to your subjects, and frightful to all the world beside, you'll do right to hear me first, and turn me out afterwards.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: (aside to Clorinda and Thisbe) May I become a commoner if it isn't that villain, Pedro! What wants he here?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: (rises) The business that brings me here is, to try the slipper— (all laugh) —not myself; but I ask the trial for one whose ambassador I come. She waits your Highness's tremendous permission to be allowed to—to show her foot here, and—and that's all.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Simple fool! Darest thou imagine—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Noble gentleman, I don't address myself to you, nor to any creature here. I speak only to the throne.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: (laughs) Noble ambassador, conduct thy fair mistress before us.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Great Prince, I will. Exit pompously L.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: My honoured Prince, your good nature serves but to encourage annoyance.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Nay, Alidoro, hinder me not because I am a Prince, from acting sometimes like a man. Condescension and humanity to our inferiors become all ranks.

div.stage: Music the same as ushered Cinderella to the ball heard. The Prince recognises it, starts with an exclamation of pleasure, and hastens towards entrance as Cinderella is led on by Pedro. Seeing her, he turns away disappointed)

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: (retiring to his seat) Bitter disappointment!

sp.speaker: Cin.
sp.p: (aside to Pedro) I tremble, Pedro! Did you see his looks?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: (aside to her) Don't mind his looks. Consider he's a Prince, and has a right to look as he likes.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: (aside) My eyes surely must be enchanted! 'tis Cinderella!

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: (aside) What assurance!

sp.speaker: This.
sp.p: (aside) She shall starve a whole week for this insolence!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: (aside to Cinderella) Come, now, keep your little heart up. I'll introduce you to him. Ahem! (to Prince) Most extensive Prince! Ahem! I am—I am—nobody— (becoming nervous) —and all that I can presume to say is— nothing! Speak, lady, and don't be afraid. (passes her over to R.)

sp.speaker: Cin.
sp.p: (aside) Alas! he has forgotten my features, or his affection has turned to dislike. Gracious Prince, I humbly venture into your presence to—to—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: (prompting her) Try on—

sp.speaker: Cin.
sp.p: Try on—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: The slip— (loudly) —slipper, your Princely Highness.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Thou—ah! now I observe thy face— (rises) Thou art—thou art— (aloud, hastily) Baron!

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: (runs forward) My Prince!

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: You know this female?

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: (vexed and confused) I know—that is, I have seen — (aside to Cinderella) I'll make you pay for this!

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Is she not your pretty servant?

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Noble Prince, I—I can scarcely say what she is.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: No, it's I that am his pretty servant, my Lord; but as for this sweet young—

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: (hastily aside to him) Speak, and I'll murder you!

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Alidoro! (the Prince converses apart with Alidoro respecting Cinderella's features)

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: (apart to Pedro) Be silent, and you shall be rewarded.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: (to Baron) I won't be silent, and I won't be rewarded. You killed the dear creature once already yesterday, and I won't be a participator in such suicide. (the Baron drives Pedro up the stage threatening him with his cane)

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: (mildly to Cinderella) Thou hast a face of beauty, fair maiden, like to her that—We'll not deny thee thy boon. Ascend the pedestal and try thy fortune— though heaven forefend thy triumph! (half aside)

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: (aside rubbing his hands) Now for it! Oh, princely Fairy, no tricks.

div.stage: Music.—Cinderella with emotion hastens to the pedestal. Baron and all the Ladies view her with contempt. She takes from the attendant the slipper which immediately goes on. All are amazed. Cinderella draws the other slippers from her bosom; Pedro runs to her and puts it on the other foot; jumping about delighted, he runs against the Baron, who angrily strikes him with his cane. The Fairy Queen now appears, and, with her wand, touches Cinderella, who is still on pedestal, when her dress is again changed to the identical one which she appeared in at the ball. At the same time the scene changes, showing
A fantastically Gorgeous Hall. The Fairies appear at the back.

sp.speaker: Fairy Q.
sp.p: (leads Cinderella to the Prince) Prince, let thy constancy now receive its full recompence.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Wonder and delight enwrap my soul!

sp.speaker: Fairy Q.
sp.p: My pleasing task is done. Sweet Cinderella, thou hast been humble in adversity: be modest now in greatness!

sp.speaker: Cin.
sp.p: Oh! happy Cinderella!—How has my fate changed from what I once deemed lasting misery to transporting bliss!

sp.l: Now with grief no longer bending

sp.speaker: CHORUS.
sp.l: May our griefs for ever fly!
